sense.name: a retarding physical force
sense.examples: This wing design is intended to reduce drag when the airplane is flying. A rough hull will add some drag to a sailboat. The drag of the current slowed the rowers' progress during the race.

sense.name: an abstract impediment or hindrance to progress
sense.examples: Her husband's drinking problem had become a drag on Mary's career. They worry that a growing deficit could become a drag on the economy. This cold has been a drag on my energy.

sense.name: being boring or tedious
sense.examples: Johnny thinks studying is a drag. The quiet kid was not at all the drag we thought he'd be at parties. It was such a drag to spend another evening watching home videos of their family vacations.

sense.name: clothing worn as a costume
sense.commentary: DRAG[+entity][+artifact][+clothing][+costume] Note: usually implies dress of the opposite sex (not always though)
sense.examples: You'll see some guys in drag on Castro Street in San Francisco. They went to the costume ball in Victorian drag. The actress always dressed in drag as a young tenor.

sense.name: inhalation, puff from a cigarette
sense.examples: Mary took another drag off her cigarette. John felt suddenly serene after several drags from the joint.

sense.name: the act of pulling an object
sense.examples: The body's drag from the kitchen to the garden left bloody tracks on the floor. Her drag of the log out of the driveway exhausted her.

sense.name: road or street
sense.examples: This is the main drag through town. The teenagers had a drag race on Saturday night. That was the old drag before they built the new shopping center.

sense.name: a conveyance, artifact pulled along
sense.examples: The farmer smoothed the tilled furrows with a drag. The boat appeared to be pulling some sort of large drag through the water. They use a drag to dredge this harbor.

sense.name: hunting lure for hounds to track
sense.examples: We laid a drag through the fields for the children's 'fox hunt'. The hounds happily followed the drag as though it were actually a wild animal.

sense.name: influence over others, persuasive powers
sense.examples: He's got the education but not the drag. Without drag, you shouldn't enter politics.

sense.name: basic drumming pattern in music
sense.examples: John's drum instructor showed him a new drag.
